page.title: 14Bogflowers of Dartmoor.
page.content: When walking Dartmoor in the summer keep you eyes open for the white tufts of{cotton grass.}This is generally a sign of wet boggy ground coming up. In a dry summer there are no problems, but when it is wet, beware of the cotton grass. The signs of the bog are to be looked for if you are interested in flowers. The nitrogen starved wet soil has caused some plants to become insectiverous. The commonest of these plants on the moor is the{Sundew.}Its sticky leaves close on the unwary insect crawling over it, and gives the plant much needed nitrogen. Finally there are the{orchids.}These are generally small, but give a splash of colour to the bog, yellow against the brillient green of the moss. Rare now, but still around, if you look for them.
